review.title: Manipulability of Single Transferable Vote
review.abstract: For many voting rules, it is NP-hard to compute a successful manipulation. However, NP-hardness only bounds the worst-case complexity. Recent theoretical results suggest that manipulation may often be easy in practice. We study empirically the cost of manipulating the single transferable vote (STV) rule. This was one of the first rules shown to be NP-hard to manipulate. It also appears to be one of the harder rules to manipulate since it involves multiple rounds and since, unlike many other rules, it is NP-hard for a single agent to manipulate without weights on the votes or uncertainty about how the other agents have voted. In almost every election in our experiments, it was easy to compute how a single agent could manipulate the election or to prove that manipulation by a single agent was impossible. It remains an interesting open question if manipulation by a coalition of agents is hard to compute in practice.
histories: Proceedings of the CARE'09 International Workshop on Collaborative Agents -- REsearch and Development, Melbourne 2009
review.COMMENTS: Proceedings of the CARE'09 International Workshop on Collaborative Agents -- REsearch and Development, Melbourne 2009

metadata.title: Manipulability of Single Transferable Vote

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: One problem is the possibility of agents trying to manipulate such an election by misreporting their preferences in order to achieve a better result. Fortunately, it is often mathematically difficult to find successful manipulation [1]. For example, Bartholdi and Orlin have proven that the Single Transferable Vote (STV) rule NP is difficult to manipulate [2]. This remains one of the few commonly used electoral rules that NP is difficult to manipulate without weighting votes, or uncertainty about how the other agents voted. NP hardness is only a worst-case outcome and cannot reflect the difficulty of manipulation in practice. Indeed, a number of recent theoretical results suggest that manipulation can often be mathematically simple [3,4,5,6,7]. Most recently Walsh has suggested that empirical studies could provide insights into the computational complexity of manipulation that can supplement such theoretical results.

sections.heading: 2 Manipulating STV
sections.text: Individual Transferable Vote (STV) runs in a number of rounds. We look at the case of the election of a single winner. Each agent lists the candidates in full. Unless a candidate has a majority of the first votes, we eliminate the candidate with the least number of first votes. All votes that put the eliminated candidate in first place are reallocated to the second-placed candidate. We then repeat until a candidate has a majority. STV is used in a variety of elections, including the Irish Presidency, the Australian House of Representatives, the Academy Awards and many societies and organizations, including the American Political Science Association, the International Olympic Committee and the British Labour Party. As in previous studies, we assume that the agents who manipulate the election know all the other votes. The problem with manipulation is to decide how the manipulators should vote, perhaps other than their true preferences, so that a selected candidate wins.

sections.heading: 3 Uniform votes
sections.text: We start with one of the simplest possible scenarios: elections in which every vote is equally likely. We have an agent trying to manipulate an election of m candidates in which n vote for other agents. Votes are drawn evenly from all m! possible votes. This is the model of the Impartial Culture (IC).

sections.heading: 3.1 Varying number of candidates
sections.text: Figures 1 and 2 show the probability that a manipulator will win a random agent, and the search to calculate whether this is possible if we specify the number of agents, but the number of candidates varies. In this and subsequent experiments, we tested 1,000 problems at each point. Unless otherwise stated, the number of candidates m and the number of agents n in potencies vary from 1 to 128. The number of voting agents is fixed and we vary the number of candidates. In contrast to phase transition behavior [12] in areas such as satisfaction [13,14], satisfaction of limitations [15,16], partitioning of numbers [17,18], graphic coloring [19,20] and expectation of the election decreases. In contrast to phase transition behavior [12] in areas such as satisfaction [13,14], satisfaction of limitations [15,16], variation of numbers [17,18], deviation of numbers [19,20] and the problem of the person sending [21].

sections.heading: 3.2 Varying number of agents
sections.text: In Figures 3 and 4, we show the probability that a manipulator can let a random agent win, and the cost of calculating whether this is possible if we determine the number of candidates but the number of agents in the election varies. An agent's ability to manipulate the election decreases as the number of agents increases. Only if there are few votes and few candidates, there is a significant chance that the manipulator will be able to change the result. Finding manipulation or not is easy unless we have both a large number of agents and a large number of candidates. In this situation, however, the probability that the manipulator can change the result is very low.

sections.heading: 4 Urn model
sections.text: To investigate the effects of a stronger correlation between the votes, we looked at random votes drawn from the Polya Eggenberg urn model [24]. In this model, we have an urn containing all the m! possible votes. We pull votes from the ballot box at random and put them back into the ballot box with an additional vote of the same type (where a is a parameter). To give a parameter regardless of the size of the problem, we look at b = am!. For example, with b = 1, there is a 50% chance that the second vote is the same as the first. In Figures 5 and 6, we plot the probability that a manipulator can win a random agent and the cost of calculation if this is possible, since we vary the number of candidates in an election in which votes are drawn from the Polya Eggenberg urn model.

sections.heading: 5 Sampling real elections
sections.text: For example, there may be some votes that are never cast. On the other hand, with the models studied so far, any possible vote with a probability is non-zero. We sampled some real voting records [25,26]. Our first experiment used the votes from 10 The number of voting agents is set, and we vary the number of candidates. The y axis measures the probability that the manipulator can win a random candidate. Teams of scientists chose one of 32 different trajectories for NASA's Mariner spacecraft. [27] Each team ranked the different trajectories based on their scientific value. We sampled these votes. For elections with 10 or fewer voting agents, we simply took a subset of the 10 votes. For elections with more than 10 agents, we chose the same number to rate them with uniform frequency. For elections with 32 or fewer candidates, we simply took a random subordination of the 32 candidates.

sections.heading: 6 Related work
sections.text: They have also conducted an empirical study that shows that only relatively small coalitions are necessary to change the elimination sequence of the STV rule. They have observed that most uniform and random elections are not trivially manipulatable using a simple greedy heuristics. On the other hand, our results suggest that manipulation by a single agent requires a limited degree of reverse to find a manipulation or prove that none exists. Walsh empirically examines the costs of manipulating the veto rule by a coalition of agents whose votes were weighted [8]. He has shown that there was a smooth transition in the likelihood that a coalition could elect a desired candidate as the size of the manipulating coalition increases. He has also shown that it was easy to find manipulations of the veto rule or to prove that there are no independent and identically distributed voices for many, even if the coalition of the manipulating class was critical.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions
sections.text: We have empirically investigated whether computational complexity is an obstacle to manipulation of the STV rule. We have looked at a number of different distributions of votes, including uniform random votes, correlated votes from a ballot model, and votes from some real-world elections. We have looked at manipulation by a single actor and a coalition of actors voting together. In contrast to phase transition behavior in areas such as satisfaction, we have not observed rapid transitions in the manipulation of STV elections, which are aggravated by a fixed point, but rather fluid transitions. We have also not observed hard cases around the transition in tamability. In fact, almost every one of the millions of elections in our experiments was easy to manipulate or prove that it could not be manipulated. Our results suggest that it may be easy for a single actor to calculate a manipulation or to prove that no election with a hundred or fewer actors and candidates is possible.

referenceMentions.context: Fortunately, it is often computationally difficult to find a successful manipulation [1].
For example, Bartholdi and Orlin proved that the Single Transferable Vote (STV) rule is NP-hard to manipulate [2].
Indeed, a number of recent theoretical results suggest that manipulation can often be computationally easy [3,4,5,6,7].

Indeed, a number of recent theoretical results suggest that manipulation can often be computationally easy [3,4,5,6,7].
Most recently, Walsh has suggested that empirical studies might provide insights into the computational complexity of manipulation that can complement such theoretical results [8].

For example, it is NP-hard to manipulate by a single voter if the number of candidates is unbounded and votes are unweighted [2], or by a coalition of voters if there are 3 or more candidates and votes are weighted (or votes are unweighted but there is uncertainty about the votes) [9].

For example, it is NP-hard to manipulate by a single voter if the number of candidates is unbounded and votes are unweighted [2], or by a coalition of voters if there are 3 or more candidates and votes are weighted (or votes are unweighted but there is uncertainty about the votes) [9].

Coleman and Teague give an enumerative method for a coalition of k unweighted voters to compute a manipulation of the STV rule which runs in O(m!(n+mk)) time where n is the number of voters and m is the number of candidates [10].

Unlike phase transition behaviour [12] in domains like satisfiability [13,14], constraint satisfaction [15,16], number partitioning [17,18], graph colouring [19,20] and the traveling salesperson problem [21], the probability curve does not appear to sharpen to a step function around a fixed point.

Unlike phase transition behaviour [12] in domains like satisfiability [13,14], constraint satisfaction [15,16], number partitioning [17,18], graph colouring [19,20] and the traveling salesperson problem [21], the probability curve does not appear to sharpen to a step function around a fixed point.

Unlike phase transition behaviour [12] in domains like satisfiability [13,14], constraint satisfaction [15,16], number partitioning [17,18], graph colouring [19,20] and the traveling salesperson problem [21], the probability curve does not appear to sharpen to a step function around a fixed point.

Unlike phase transition behaviour [12] in domains like satisfiability [13,14], constraint satisfaction [15,16], number partitioning [17,18], graph colouring [19,20] and the traveling salesperson problem [21], the probability curve does not appear to sharpen to a step function around a fixed point.
The probability curve resembles the smooth phase transitions seen in polynomial problems like 2-coloring [22] and 1in-2 satisfiability [23].

To study the impact of more correlation between votes, we considered random votes drawn from the Polya Eggenberger urn model [24].
We therefore sampled some real voting records [25,26].

In our second experiment, we used votes from a faculty hiring committee at the University of California at Irvine [28].
Coleman and Teague proposed algorithms to compute a manipulation for the STV rule [10].
Walsh empirically studied the cost of manipulating the veto rule by a coalition of agents whose votes were weighted [8].

For instance, Xia and Conitzer have shown that for a large class of voting rules including STV, as the number of agents grows, either the probability that a coalition can manipulate the result is very small (as the coalition is too small), or the probability that they can easily manipulate the result to make any alternative win is very large [5].

As a second example, Procaccia and Rosenschein proved that for most scoring rules and a wide variety of distributions over votes, when the size of the coalition is o( √ n), the probability that they can change the result tends to 0, and when it is ω( √ n), the probability that they can manipulate the result tends to 1 [29].
They also gave a simple greedy procedure that will find a manipulation of a scoring rule in polynomial time with a probability of failure that is an inverse polynomial in n [4].
then there exists an agent for whom a random manipulation succeeds with probability Ω( 1 n ) [6].

Starting from different assumptions, Xia and Conitzer showed that a random manipulation would succeed with probability Ω( 1 n ) for 3 or more candidates for STV, for 4 or more candidates for any scoring rule and for 5 or more candidates for Copeland [7].
These two rules have only recently been shown to be NP-hard to manipulate, and are members of the small set of voting rules which are NP-hard to manipulate without weights or uncertainty [30].

metadata.abstractText: For many voting rules, it is NP-hard to compute a successful manipulation. However, NP-hardness only bounds the worst-case complexity. Recent theoretical results suggest that manipulation may often be easy in practice. We study empirically the cost of manipulating the single transferable vote (STV) rule. This was one of the first rules shown to be NP-hard to manipulate. It also appears to be one of the harder rules to manipulate since it involves multiple rounds and since, unlike many other rules, it is NP-hard for a single agent to manipulate without weights on the votes or uncertainty about how the other agents have voted. In almost every election in our experiments, it was easy to compute how a single agent could manipulate the election or to prove that manipulation by a single agent was impossible. It remains an interesting open question if manipulation by a coalition of agents is hard to compute in practice.
